Question: A gardener wants to determine if a new fertilizer increases tomato plant growth.
She has 10 tomato seedlings of the same variety that she planted on the same day.

Design an experiment to test the effectiveness of the fertilizer, explaining what the control variables should be, what the experimental variable is, and how to set up a proper control group for comparison.

Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so the gardener wants to figure out if a new fertilizer helps tomatoes grow better.
She has 10 seedlings, same variety, planted on the same day.
That's a good setup because it controls for variables like planting time, soil type, etc.
First, I need to think about what the main question is: does the fertilizer affect growth? So, the experiment should show a difference between the fertilizer group and the control group.
What are the control variables here? Well, since all seedlings are from the same variety and planted on the same day, that already helps.
But maybe I should make sure they're in the same environment.
So, location in the garden should be the same for all.
Also, watering—probably the same amount and method, unless the fertilizer's effect is due to watering.
But the fertilizer is the variable, so watering should be controlled.
Maybe she uses the same watering can and water them equally.

So, the control variables are: type of plant (all tomatoes), planting date, location in garden, watering frequency and amount, soil preparation, maybe sunlight exposure if different areas get more sun.
The experimental variable is the fertilizer treatment.
So, half the plants get the new fertilizer, and half don't.
That way, any differences can be attributed to the fertilizer.
Setting up the control group: these are the plants without the fertilizer.
They should be treated the same as the experimental group except for the fertilizer.
So, same watering, same soil, same care.
Wait, but maybe the gardener uses a different approach.
Like, maybe she uses a randomized block design, where each plant is either treated or not, but that's similar.
Or she could have two groups: one with fertilizer, one without.
Then, measure growth after a set time, like a month or two.
But how do you measure growth? Maybe the height, number of leaves, number of fruits, weight.
But since it's early, maybe just height and number of leaves.
Or she could measure at the end of the season for the final yield.
I think the key is to have a proper control group to compare against.
So, the control group is the plants without the fertilizer, and the experimental group is the ones with it.
Both groups get the same care otherwise.
So, in summary, the experiment involves dividing the 10 plants into two groups: one gets the fertilizer, the other doesn't.
Control variables like planting time, location, watering, soil are kept the same.
Then, after some time, compare growth between the two groups.

</think>

To determine if the new fertilizer increases tomato plant growth, the gardener can design an experiment by dividing the 10 seedlings into two groups of 5 each.
One group will receive the new fertilizer, and the other will serve as the control group without the fertilizer.
Control variables such as planting date, location, watering frequency, and soil preparation will be kept consistent for both groups.
After a set period (e.g., a month or the end of the growing season), the gardener will measure growth metrics like height, number of leaves, and yield to compare the two groups.
This setup ensures that any observed differences can be attributed to the fertilizer.
